sourcesContent:
const books = [
    { 
        id: 1, 
        author: 'Leo Tolstoy', 
        title: 'War and Peace', 
        available: true, 
        description: "Often considered the greatest novel ever written, this is world literature's defining epic, and the first novel to achieve something unprecedented: merging intimate human drama with historical philosophy. Its genius establishes the idea that the smallest personal drama – a girl's first dance, a prisoner sharing bread – carry equal weight to Napoleon’s campaigns. In a world in tumult, historical forces test the individual will. Fiction can contain the sweep of history and the flutter of a single heart.",
        category: 'Historical Fiction'
    },
    { 
        id: 2, 
        author: 'George Elliot', 
        title: "Middlemarch", 
        available: false, 
        description: "George Eliot revolutionised the novel by presenting a complete social web of human relationships with unprecedented psychological depth. Its greatness lies in showing how private lives and social forces interweave, while its intimate portrayal of intellectual women's struggles for meaning created a new kind of psychological realism. It's considered the peak of Victorian fiction because it captured both individual consciousness and society's moral fabric with unmatched sophistication.",
        category: 'Historical Fiction'
    },
    { 
        id: 3, 
        author: 'Mary Shelly', 
        title: "Frankenstein", 
        available: false, 
        description: "A philosophical exploration of faith, doubt, and morality, centered around the tumultuous lives of three brothers in Russia.",
        category: 'Classics'
    },
    { 
        id: 4, 
        author: 'Henry James', 
        title: 'Portrait of a Lady', 
        available: false, 
        description: "This book marks the moment the novel became truly psychological, with James's detailed exploration of consciousness, perception and choice. Its mastery lies in showing how an independent mind navigates social constraints, while revolutionising narrative technique through psychological intimacy. It's essential because it pushed fiction beyond plot into the territory of pure consciousness.",
        category: 'Classics'
    },
    { 
        id: 5, 
        author: 'James Joyce', 
        title: 'Finnegans Wake', 
        available: false, 
        description: "A witty and romantic exploration of class and social standing in 19th-century England, following the lives of the Bennet sisters.",
        category: 'Classics'
    },
    { 
        id: 6, 
        author: 'Virginia Woolf', 
        title: 'Mrs Dalloway', 
        available: false, 
        description: "The tale of a young orphan named Pip, whose journey of self-discovery is shaped by wealth, betrayal, and unrequited love.",
        category: 'Classics'
    },
    { 
        id: 7, 
        author: 'Charlotte Perkins Gilman', 
        title: 'The Yellow Wallpaper', 
        available: false, 
        description: "A profound tale of obsession, fate, and vengeance, following Captain Ahab's relentless pursuit of the elusive white whale, Moby-Dick.",
        category: 'Adventure'
    },
    { 
        id: 8, 
        author: 'Fyodor Dostoyevsky', 
        title: 'The Idiot', 
        available: false, 
        description: "A groundbreaking work of science fiction and horror, telling the story of a scientist who creates life with disastrous consequences.",
        category: 'Science Fiction'
    },
    { 
        id: 9, 
        author: 'Thomas Mann', 
        title: 'Buddenbrooks', 
        available: false, 
        description: "A beloved fantasy adventure that follows Bilbo Baggins on a perilous journey to reclaim a lost kingdom from a fierce dragon.",
        category: 'Fantasy'
    },
    { 
        id: 10, 
        author: 'H.G. Wells', 
        title: 'Time Machine', 
        available: false, 
        description: "A mesmerizing tale of magical realism, chronicling the lives of the Buendía family in the mythical town of Macondo.",
        category: 'Classics'
    }
]
export default books
